awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Cryogen-Free Physical Property Measurement System for Research and Education at Ohio University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a Quantum Design Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS) –an automated multi-functional instrument for electrical, magnetic, and optical measurements on semiconductors, superconductors, organic thin films, and low dimensional materials. This instrument supports rapidly expanding research activity in the field of nano-science, including 2D materials as well as flexible electronics and device engineering at Ohio University. Furthermore, the training and education afforded by this equipment has very significant societal implications and is expected to make significant contributions toward the development of a technically-educated workforce in the Appalachian corner of the State of Ohio.  The cross-cutting nature of this equipment reinforces research and education endeavors locally and fosters new research directions in several areas of basic science and applied nanotechnology.  

This MRI award supports the acquisition of a Quantum Design Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS) – an open architecture and automated multi-functional instrument for electrical, magnetic, and optical measurements The broad spectrum of research projects directly impacted by the PPMS includes the growth and characterization of i) novel nanomaterials and composites, ii) established and emerging 2D materials and heterostructures, iii) printed and deposited thin films of polymers and composites, iv) magnetic nanoparticles, v) superconducting materials and structures, and vi) carbon-based composite materials. These projects sustain unique and advanced research programs in south-eastern Ohio by enabling the exploration of new materials and physical effects. By doing so, the projects make possible progress toward developing low-cost materials, with engineered properties, that could enable a range of novel device technologies critical to modern electronics and consumer applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
(PI) W. Jadwisienczak; (Co-PIs) K. A. Cimatu, S. Kaya, F. Rahman, E. Stinaff

The Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS) arrived on campus in March 2021, but because of the COVID pandemic, installation was completed only in June 2022. Since fall 2022, the co-PIs developed and implemented the training procedure and user protocols required for the independent and supervised operation of the facility, which is currently fully operational and supports R&D and entrepreneurial activities across campus as well as collaboration with other universities, and industrial partners primarily through the Intel ®Semiconductor Education and Research Program for Ohio.

Intellectual Merit: 

This instrument supports rapidly expanding research in nanoscience at OHIO, allowing accurate physical parameter characterizations for the development of novel functional materials and advanced device structures including i) novel nanomaterials and composites, ii) established and emerging 2D materials and heterostructures, iii) printed and deposited thin films of polymers and composites, iv) magnetic nanoparticles, v) superconducting materials and structures, and vi) carbon-based composite materials.

The PPMS facility strengthened the PIs’ research competitiveness and created collaboration opportunities with domestic and international academia and industrial partners including Intel and the National Center for Defense Manufacturing and Machining to Support NEOEx Systems, Inc. as subcontractors.

Broader Impacts:

PPMS facility is an integral part of the research and education efforts related to the Appalachian Semiconductor Education and Technical (ASCENT) Ecosystem to facilitate workforce development for Ohio’s emerging semiconductor industry and career opportunities created by Intel’s arrival to Ohio. The PPMS facility enabled the curriculum development of a new purely lab-oriented course, EE6900 Analytical Instruments and Microscopy Lab. As a part of larger outreach efforts related to Intel-funded projects at Ohio universities, the co-PIs co-hosted the Semiconductor Workshop for Teachers and Professions (June 14 -16, 2023) for science teachers, regional campus and community college faculty, and engineering industry professionals interested in the fundamentals of semiconductor technology, microfabrication, and workforce. A cohort of 20+ individuals was introduced to the PPMS facility, various measurement options, and semiconductor-related activities.

Publications and other Products resulting from the NSF award:

There are two papers resulting from this award [Refs.1,2]. Other Products include physical and cyber resources and facilities available to interested parties requesting unpublished research data, specimens, and educational materials including: (1) measurable data and physical parameters are available through the open-access journals after data is published, (2) physical research specimens are available for interested parties by contacting involved PIs at Ohio University, and (3) curriculum materials will be accessible at individual PIs and their relevant academic units’ websites after offering the new EE6900 Analytical Instruments and Microscopy Lab course in Fall 2024.

[WJ1] F. P. N. Inbanathan, K. L. A. Cimatu, D. C. Ingram, U. J. Erasquin, K. Dasari, M. S. Sultan, M. Sajjad, V. I. Makarov, B. R. Weiner, G. Morell, P. S. Abdar, and W. M. Jadwisienczak, Paramagnetism in Microwave Synthesized Metal-Free Nitrogen-doped Graphene Quantum Dots, Materials 2023, 16, 3410.

[WJ2] M. S. Sultan, V. I. Makarov, F. Mendoza, M. Sajjad, D. Barrionuevo, Flavia. P. N. Inhanathan, U. I. Premadasa, K. L. A. Cimatu, W. M. Jadwisienczak, K. Habiba, B. R. Weiner, G. Morell, Superparamagnetic Properties of Metal-Free Nitrogen-Doped Graphene Quantum Dots. In review, JAP, JAP23-AR-03411.


Last Modified: 01/07/2024
Modified by: Wojciech M Jadwisienczak
